user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of ws_receive_frame:
```c
static unsigned char *
ws_receive_frame (unsigned char *frame, ssize_t *length, int *type)
{
  unsigned char masks[4];
  unsigned char mask;
  unsigned char *msg;
  unsigned char flength;
  unsigned char idx_first_mask;
  unsigned char idx_first_data;
  size_t data_length;
  int i;
  int j;

  msg = NULL;
  if (frame[0] == (WS_FIN | WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME))
  {
    *type = WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME;
    idx_first_mask = 2;
    mask = frame[1];
    flength = mask & 0x7F;
    if (flength == 126)
    {
      idx_first_mask = 4;
    }
    else if (flength == 127)
    {
      idx_first_mask = 10;
    }
    idx_first_data = (unsigned char) (idx_first_mask + 4);
    data_length = (size_t) *length - idx_first_data;
    masks[0] = frame[idx_first_mask + 0];
    masks[1] = frame[idx_first_mask + 1];
    masks[2] = frame[idx_first_mask + 2];
    masks[3] = frame[idx_first_mask + 3];
    msg = malloc (data_length + 1);
    if (NULL != msg)
    {
      for (i = idx_first_data, j = 0; i < *length; i++, j++)
      {
        msg[j] = frame[i] ^ masks[j % 4];
      }
      *length = (ssize_t) data_length;
      msg[j] = '\0';
    }
  }
  else if (frame[0] == (WS_FIN | WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME))
  {
    *type = WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME;
  }
  else
  {
    *type = frame[0] & 0x0F;
  }
  return msg;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function ws_receive_frame:
#define WS_FIN 128
...
#define WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME 1
...
#define WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME 8
...
static void *
run_usock (void *cls)
{
  struct WsData *ws = cls;
  struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh = ws->urh;
  unsigned char buf[2048];
  unsigned char *msg;
  char *text;
  ssize_t got;
  int type;
  int i;

  make_blocking (ws->sock);
  while (1)
  {
    got = recv (ws->sock, (void *) buf, sizeof (buf), 0);
    if (0 >= got)
    {
      break;
    }
    msg = ws_receive_frame (buf, &got, &type);
    if (NULL == msg)
    {
      break;
    }
    if (type == WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME)
    {
      ssize_t sent;
      int buf_size;
      buf_size = snprintf (NULL, 0, "User#%d: %s", (int) ws->sock, msg);
      if (0 < buf_size)
      {
        text = malloc ((size_t) buf_size + 1);
        if (NULL != text)
        {
          if (snprintf (text, (size_t) buf_size + 1,
                        "User#%d: %s", (int) ws->sock, msg) == buf_size)
            sent = ws_send_frame (ws->sock, text, (size_t) buf_size);
          else
            sent = -1;
          free (text);
        }
        else
          sent = -1;
      }
      else
        sent = -1;
      free (msg);
      if (-1 == sent)
      {
        break;
      }
    }
    else
    {
      if (type == WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME)
      {
        free (msg);
        break;
      }
    }
  }
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_lock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  for (i = 0; i < MAX_CLIENTS; i++)
  {
    if (CLIENT_SOCKS[i] == ws->sock)
    {
      CLIENT_SOCKS[i] = MHD_INVALID_SOCKET;
      break;
    }
  }
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_unlock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  free (ws);
  MHD_upgrade_action (urh, MHD_UPGRADE_ACTION_CLOSE);
  return NULL;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The key issue is the interaction between ws_receive_frame and run_usock: ws_receive_frame returns NULL for non-text frames (including the CON_CLOSE_FRAME case) while still setting *type. In run_usock the code immediately breaks out of the receive loop if msg is NULL, so any subsequent handling that relies on type for non-text frames will not be reached. Therefore the specific fragments selected above should be investigated. Other code fragments (the body of the text-frame processing, the masking/unmasking loop and allocation in ws_receive_frame, and the normal recv/cleanup logic) are not flagged because they are reachable and follow a consistent control flow: ws_receive_frame returns a non-NULL msg only for text frames, and the corresponding processing in run_usock is reachable and exercised when msg is non-NULL.
